text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Policy
and Law Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on Security - Security
Management. According to news reporting originating in Ogden, Utah, by NewsRx
journalists, research stated, "The current study examines identity fraud
victimization within a college student sample. Concepts from the lifestyle-
routine activity approach, specifically exposure and proximity to motivated
offenders, as well as the personality trait of low self-control, are examined
as potential explanations for identity fraud."

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Weber State
University, "The knock-on relationship between hacking and identity fraud is
also of interest. Using data from a sample of college students at a Midwestern
university in the U.S., and structural equation modeling techniques, the
findings suggest that peer deviance, low self-control, and hacking
victimization are directly related to identity fraud, whereas the relationship
between personal deviance and identity fraud victimization operates indirectly
through hacking."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Overall, the results
support lifestyle-routine activities and low self-control as theoretical
explanations of identity fraud victimization."

For more information on this research see: No honor among thieves: personal
and peer deviance as explanations of online identity fraud victimization.
_Security Journal_ , 2020;33(2):228-243. _Security Journal_ can be contacted
at: Palgrave Macmillan Ltd, Brunel Rd Bldg, Houndmills, Basingstoke RG21 6XS,
Hants, England.

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting B.W. Reyns, Weber State University, Ogden, UT 84408, United States.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1057/s41284-019-00182-w>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers from Weber State University Detail New Studies and Findings in the Area of Security Management (No honor among thieves: personal and peer deviance as explanations of online identity fraud victimization): Security - Security Management
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Policy and Law Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Security - Security Management. According to news reporting originating in Ogden, Utah, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “The current study examines identity fraud victimization within a college student sample. Concepts from the lifestyle-routine activity approach, specifically exposure and proximity to motivated offenders, as well as the personality trait of low self-control, are examined as potential explanations for identity fraud.”

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Weber State University, “The knock-on relationship between hacking and identity fraud is also of interest. Using data from a sample of college students at a Midwestern university in the U.S., and structural equation modeling techniques, the findings suggest that peer deviance, low self-control, and hacking victimization are directly related to identity fraud, whereas the relationship between personal deviance and identity fraud victimization operates indirectly through hacking.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “Overall, the results support lifestyle-routine activities and low self-control as theoretical explanations of identity fraud victimization.”

For more information on this research see: No honor among thieves: personal and peer deviance as explanations of online identity fraud victimization. Security Journal, 2020;33(2):228-243. Security Journal can be contacted at: Palgrave Macmillan Ltd, Brunel Rd Bldg, Houndmills, Basingstoke RG21 6XS, Hants, England.

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting B.W. Reyns, Weber State University, Ogden, UT 84408, United States.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1057/s41284-019-00182-w. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
